Predicting across sub-models

Alex Hayes

2018-09-13

Source: vignettes/predicting-across-sub-models.Rmd
predicting-across-sub-models.Rmd

In some cases there are computationally efficient tricks to get predictions for multiple fits from the same model1.

Current thoughts on interface:

library(glmnet)
#> Loading required package: Matrix
#> Loading required package: foreach
#> Loaded glmnet 2.0-16

x <- matrix(rnorm(100 * 5), 100, 5)
y <-  x[, 1] * 3 + rnorm(100)
fit <- cv.glmnet(x, y)
test <- matrix(rnorm(10 * 5), 10, 5)
diag(test) <- NA

Prediction at a single value of lambda

library(tibble)
library(safepredict)

safe_predict(fit, test, params = "1-se")
#> # A tibble: 10 x 1
#>       .pred
#>       <dbl>
#>  1  NA     
#>  2  -0.781 
#>  3  -0.134 
#>  4  -3.24  
#>  5   0.0265
#>  6   2.77  
#>  7   2.43  
#>  8  -3.00  
#>  9  -3.77  
#> 10  -0.551
safe_predict(fit, test, params = "min")
#> # A tibble: 10 x 1
#>       .pred
#>       <dbl>
#>  1  NA     
#>  2  -0.857 
#>  3  -0.146 
#>  4  -3.56  
#>  5   0.0309
#>  6   3.05  
#>  7   2.67  
#>  8  -3.30  
#>  9  -4.14  
#> 10  -0.605
safe_predict(fit, test, params = 0.1)
#> # A tibble: 10 x 1
#>       .pred
#>       <dbl>
#>  1  NA     
#>  2  -0.874 
#>  3  NA     
#>  4  -3.58  
#>  5   0.0246
#>  6   3.08  
#>  7   2.69  
#>  8  -3.35  
#>  9  -4.17  
#> 10  -0.598

Predictions for many lambda at once

Now we need to keep track of the observation that a prediction belongs to, and also \(\lambda\), so we add two new columns: id and lambda.

grid <- tibble(lambda = 1:10)

safe_predict(fit, test, type = "param_pred", params = grid)
#> # A tibble: 100 x 3
#>       id lambda    .pred
#>    <int> <chr>     <dbl>
#>  1     1 1       NA     
#>  2     2 1       -0.615 
#>  3     3 1       -0.109 
#>  4     4 1       -2.54  
#>  5     5 1        0.0170
#>  6     6 1        2.16  
#>  7     7 1        1.89  
#>  8     8 1       -2.35  
#>  9     9 1       -2.95  
#> 10    10 1       -0.435 
#> # ... with 90 more rows

Predicting across binomial sub-models with glmnet 

y2 <- as.factor(rep(LETTERS[1:2], each = 50))

x2 <-  rbind(
  matrix(rnorm(50 * 3), 50, 3),
  matrix(rnorm(50 * 3, 10), 50, 3)
)

test2 <- head(x2, 10)
diag(test2) <- NA

fit2 <- cv.glmnet(x2,  y2, family = "binomial")

NOTE: here we have already specified type, so we canâ€™t pick between "prob" and "class" and just get class probabilities. Iâ€™m not a huge fan of this.

safe_predict(fit2, test2, type = "param_pred", params = grid)
#> # A tibble: 100 x 4
#>       id lambda .pred_A .pred_B
#>    <int>  <int>   <dbl>   <dbl>
#>  1     1      1   0.500     0.5
#>  2     2      1   0.500     0.5
#>  3     3      1   0.500     0.5
#>  4     4      1   0.500     0.5
#>  5     5      1   0.500     0.5
#>  6     6      1   0.500     0.5
#>  7     7      1   0.500     0.5
#>  8     8      1   0.500     0.5
#>  9     9      1   0.500     0.5
#> 10    10      1   0.500     0.5
#> # ... with 90 more rows

Predicting across multinomial sub-models

y3 <-  sample(LETTERS[1:5], 100, replace = TRUE)
fit3 <- cv.glmnet(x, y3, family = "multinomial")

safe_predict(fit3, test, type = "param_pred", params = grid)
#> # A tibble: 100 x 7
#>       id lambda .pred_A .pred_B .pred_C .pred_D .pred_E
#>    <int>  <int>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>
#>  1     1      1    0.13    0.26    0.18    0.21    0.22
#>  2     2      1    0.13    0.26    0.18    0.21    0.22
#>  3     3      1    0.13    0.26    0.18    0.21    0.22
#>  4     4      1    0.13    0.26    0.18    0.21    0.22
#>  5     5      1    0.13    0.26    0.18    0.21    0.22
#>  6     6      1    0.13    0.26    0.18    0.21    0.22
#>  7     7      1    0.13    0.26    0.18    0.21    0.22
#>  8     8      1    0.13    0.26    0.18    0.21    0.22
#>  9     9      1    0.13    0.26    0.18    0.21    0.22
#> 10    10      1    0.13    0.26    0.18    0.21    0.22
#> # ... with 90 more rows

The behavior for multivariate gaussian families is essentially the same.

NOTE: currently the user has always has to specify type. Iâ€™m trying to decide if I like this or if itâ€™s somewhat verbose.

Next steps: A demonstration of sub-model prediction for a model with more than one hyperparameter

  1. Some terminology: a model is a family of probability distributions or functions. That is, a model is a set. An estimator is a way to calculate the parameters of a model from a dataset. The value of an estimator may depend on hyperparameters, which influence estimation but not the model. For example, \(\lambda\) is a hyperparameter for the LASSO estimator for the linear model. The resulting estimates are a fit (sometimes referred to in the tidymodels universe as a sub-model).â†©
